title-group.article-title: A Novel “Personalized Safe Zone” for Acetabular Cup Placement During Total Hip Arthroplasty in Patients With Spinopelvic Pathology: Concept, Construction, and Clinical Application

aff.institution: First Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University
The Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University
First Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University
Cixi Integrated Chinese and Western Medicine Medical Health Group (Cixi Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine)

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). Orthopaedic Surgery published by Tianjin Hospital and John Wiley & Sons Australia, Ltd.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: A higher risk of dislocation was still found in patients with spinopelvic disorders, despite the acetabular cup was placed within the classical “Lewinnek safe zone.” This study aimed to reveal the risk factors of acetabular cup placement during total hip arthroplasty (THA) in patients with spinopelvic pathology, construct and validate a novel “Personalized Safe Zone” based on the Hip‐Spine Classification System (HSCS) to reduce the prosthetic impingement and dislocation in these patients.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: One retrospective study was conducted on patients with spinopelvic pathologies underwent the primary THA admitted to the First Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University from January 2017 and May 2023. According to the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the general information (Age, gender, Primary disease, Side, BMI) and radiological parameters of patients were collected, including spinal parameters (pelvic incidence [PI], pelvic tilt [PT], sacral slope [SS], lumbar lordosis angle [LL], sagittal vertical axis, thoracic kyphosis angle, cobb angle), pelvic parameters (cup inclination [CI], cup anteversion [CA], disparity in bilateral femoral offset), and spinopelvic parameters (absolute value of PI minus LL [|PI‐LL|], change of sacral slope [ΔSS], combined sagittal index [CSI]). The correlation between the above parameters and prosthesis dislocation after THA was assessed and a clinical prediction model was constructed by R language. Subsequently, the ranges of “Personalized Safe Zone” for the acetabular cup placement in the four subgroups classified by the HSCS, were defined as the mean ± standard deviation of CA and CI in each nondislocation subgroup, and were validated by a cohort study.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were correlations between ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, standing CSI and anterior dislocation, ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, sitting CSI and posterior dislocation. The ranges of “Personalized Safe Zone” in each subgroup were as follows: 1A (CA = 14.11° ± 4.57°, CI = 38.65° ± 6.32°), 1B (CA = 17.23° ± 3.15°, CI = 38.19° ± 5.45°), 2A (CA = 15.76° ± 4.08°, CI = 38.95° ± 6.21°), 2B (CA = 19.50° ± 3.73°, CI = 39.50° ± 6.48°). Moreover, a significant reduction in prosthesis dislocation and impingement was investigated, when the acetabular cup was placed according to the “Personalized Safe Zone.”

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: These parameters, including ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, CSI should be fully considered when placing acetabular cup during THA and the novel “Personalized Safe Zone” could reduce the dislocation and prosthetic impingement after THA in patients with spinopelvic pathology.

abstract.p: This study aimed to reveal the risk factors of acetabular cup placement during THA in patients with pinopelvic pathology, construct and validate a novel “Personalized Safe Zone” based on the Hip‐Spine Classification System. Our results showed that these parameters related to prosthesis dislocation, including ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, CSI should be emphasized when placing acetabular cup during THA in patients with spinopelvic pathology. The novel “Personalized Safe Zone” could reduce the dislocation and prosthetic impingement after THA in these patients.

p.mixed-citation: X.Wan, T.Li, J.Liu, et al., “A Novel “Personalized Safe Zone” for Acetabular Cup Placement During Total Hip Arthroplasty in Patients With Spinopelvic Pathology: Concept, Construction, and Clinical Application,” Orthopaedic Surgery17, no. 9 (2025): 2596–2607, 10.1111/os.70129.PMC1240487740761098

fn.p: Funding: This work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (82260427), the Science and Technology Plan Project of Yunnan Province Technology Hall (202301AT070134), the Yunnan Revitalization Talent Support Program (XDYC‐QNRC‐2023‐0198), the Yunnan Province Medical Discipline Reserve Talent Project (H‐2024030), and the PhD Research Fund Project of the First Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University (2021BS016).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Total hip arthroplasty (THA) was used to release the hip pain and limb mobility impairments caused by end‐stage hip diseases [1]. The increasing number of patients underwent THA in the aging population [2]. However, prosthesis dislocation remain as one of the common complications after THA [3, 4].“Lewinnek safe zone” was previously considered as the “golden standard” for acetabular cup placement during THA for a long time [5]. However, there were more and more controversies and challenges for it [6, 7, 8], particularly in patients with spinopelvic disorders, such as rheumatoid disease, ankylosing spondylitis (AS), long‐segment spinal fusion (≥ three levels) and so on [9, 10]. A higher risk of dislocation was still found in these patients, despite the acetabular cup was placed within the “Lewinnek safe zone” [11]. Several studies demonstrated that “Lewinnek safe zone” was not entirely foolproof [6], due to that the linkage relationship between the spine and pelvis should be emphasized [12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18] based on the concepts of “functional safe zone” and “Hip‐Spine Classification System (HSCS)” [19, 20, 21]. But some limitations still existed because of the lack of precise clinical guidance for the acetabular cup placement during THA [20, 21, 22]. Therefore, this study aimed to (1) reveal the risk factors of acetabular cup placement during THA in patients with spinopelvic pathology; (2) construct a novel “Personalized Safe Zone” based on the HSCS; (3) explore its clinical effectiveness.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: The study design and data collection were approved by the Ethics Committee of xx Hospital (NO. 2025 L013).
Written informed consent was obtained from all individual participants and/or their families.

sec.title: The Risk Factors of Acetabular Cup Placement During THA in Patients With Spinopelvic Pathology
sec.p: A total of 208 patients with spinopelvic disorders who underwent primary THA in the xx Hospital between January 2017 and May 2023 were collected in this study. Inclusion criteria: (1) patients who underwent primary THA through a posterolateral approach for spinopelvic disorders, including degenerative changes, AS, spinal deformities, rheumatoid spondylitis, and so on, or those who underwent long‐segment spinal fusion (≥ three levels); (2) patients with intact clinical data including preoperative and postoperative anteroposterior, lateral standing, and sitting spine‐pelvis‐hip [18], as well as the preoperative full‐spine anteroposterior and lateral standing X‐ray [23]. Exclusion criteria: (1) patients with prosthesis dislocation caused by significant trauma or violence; (2) patients with periprosthetic fractures, infections, or THA revisions; (3) patients with prosthesis dislocation caused by neuromuscular diseases such as poliomyelitis, myasthenia, Parkinson's, and so on; (4) patients with the inability to cooperate with the researchers. The details of baseline data for each patient included age, gender, BMI, and primary disease. The participants were followed up for at least 12 months postoperatively.

The relevant radiological parameters were collected, including spinal parameters (pelvic incidence [PI], pelvic tilt [PT], sacral slope [SS], lumbar lordosis angle [LL], sagittal vertical axis [SVA], thoracic kyphosis angle [TK], cobb angle [Cob]), pelvic parameters (cup inclination [CI], cup anteversion [CA], disparity in bilateral femoral offset [ΔFO]), and spinopelvic parameters (absolute value of PI minus LL [|PI‐LL|], change of sacral slope [ΔSS], combined sagittal index [CSI]), to assess the correlation between the above parameters, prosthesis dislocation (The specific measurement methods were shown in Figure 1) and construct the clinical prediction model [24]. The measurement was conducted by an attending physician.

caption.p: Measurement of the parameters. (A) TK = Thoracic kyphosis angle (Defined as the angle formed by lines drawn along the inferior endplate of the T12 vertebra and the superior endplate of the T4 vertebra), LL = Lumbar lordosis angle (Lumbar lordosis was measured from the superior endplate of L1 to the superior endplate of S1), SVA = Sagittal vertical axis (Defined as the horizontal distance between the C7 plumb line and the posterior superior corner of the upper margin of S1). (B) Cobb = Cobb angle (Draw a horizontal line on the upper edge of the upper vertebra, and draw a horizontal line on the lower edge of the lower vertebra, and make a vertical line on each of the two horizontal lines. The intersection Angle of the two vertical lines is the Cobb Angle). (C) CA = cup anteversion (The cup anteversion is calculated using the Lewinnek's method: CA = arcsin [D1/D2]), (D): CI = cup inclination, (E) ΔFO = disparity in bilateral femoral offset (FO‐FO′), (F) LLD: Leg length discrepancy (D1‐D2), (G–J) Preoperative and postoperative anteroposterior, lateral standing and sitting spine‐pelvis‐hip, PI = Pelvic incidence (The angle formed between the vertical plane of the S1 upper plate's midpoint and the line connecting the point to the dual shafts of the strand), PT = Pelvic tilt (The angle formed between the vertical line and the line connecting the midpoint and the double axis of the S1 upper plate), SS = Sacral slope (The angle formed between the horizontal plane and the upper plate of S1), PFA = pelvifemoral Angle (between the midpoint of the end plate of sacral 1 and the center of the femoral head and the axis of the femur), AI = It is done by drawing a line from the center of the femoral head to the leading edge of the acetabulum, and then drawing a line from the center of the femoral head to the posterior edge of the acetabulum. The Angle between the two lines is the rake Angle. CSI = combined sagittal index (PFA + AI).

sec.title: Construction of “Personalized Safe Zone”
sec.p: The “Personalized Safety Zone” for the acetabular cup placement was defined by two steps. Primarily, patients were classified four subgroups by the HSCS [21]: the group 1 and 2 were defined as the patients with normal spinal alignment and flatback deformity, respectively. Two subgroups (group A and B) were then classified by the spinal stiff extent. Specifically, flatback deformity was defined as |PI‐LL| < 10°, and spinal stiffness was characterized by ΔSS < 10°.

Second, the ranges of “Personalized Safe Zone” for the acetabular cup placement were defined as the mean ± standard deviation of the CA and CI in nondislocation subgroups, and the discrepancies between of them and the “Lewinnek safe zone” were estimated [5].

sec.title: Clinical Validation of “Personalized Safe Zone”
sec.p: The clinical validation of “Personalized Safe Zone” was conducted by a Cohort study approved by the same Hospital between June 2023 and November 2023. Inclusion criteria were as follows: (1) patients underwent primary THA through a posterolateral approach spinopelvic disorders, including degenerative changes, AS, spinal deformities, rheumatoid spondylitis, and so on or those underwent long‐segment spinal fusion (≥ three levels); (2) patients voluntarily participate in the trial and sign the informed consent form; (3) patients consent for required preoperative and postoperative clinical and radiographic evaluations. Exclusion criteria were as follows: (1) patients with prosthesis dislocation caused by neuromuscular diseases such as poliomyelitis, myasthenia, Parkinson, and so on (2) patients with inability to cooperate with the researchers. Notably, patients without full follow‐up data were excluded.

All these patients were divided into P‐THA group (the acetabular cup were placed by the “Personalized Safe Zone”) and T‐THA group (the acetabular cup were placed by the “Lewinnek safe zone”). All patients in both groups were treated with the same postoperative rehabilitation. The postoperative discrepancies between the two groups were observed in radiographic outcomes (CI, CA, CSI), complications (the rate of dislocation, leg length discrepancy [LLD], nerve injury), and functional recovery (Harris Hip Score [HHS], and Forgotten Joint Score‐12 [25], short‐term Vas score), to verify the clinical effectiveness of “Personalized Safe Zone.”

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Multivariate logistic regression analyses were performed to identify the independent risk of acetabular cup placement in THA influenced by Spine‐Pelvis parameters. The discrimination of the nomogram was measured by calculating the area under the receiver operating characteristic (AUROC) and the concordance index. The model calibration was determined to use the Hosmer‐Lemeshow technique, and calibration curve differences were considered significant at p < 0 0.05. Analyses were performed with the SPSS 29.0 (IBM, USA) and R version 4.4.0 (Lucent Technologies, New Zealand). The measurement data were presented as the mean ± standard deviation. ANOVA or T test was employed for analyzing intergroup variables, while the Chi‐square test was used for HSS and VAS scores. A P value of less than 0.05 indicated statistical significance.

sec.title: The Risk Factors of Acetabular Cup Placement During THA in Patients with Spinopelvic Pathology
Characteristics of Patients
sec.p: A total of 208 participants were included in this study. Their primary diseases included avascular necrosis (AVN, 113 cases, 54.33%), developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH, 30 cases, 14.42%), osteoarthritis (OA, 44 cases, 21.15%), rheumatoid arthritis (RA, five cases, 2.4%), and AS (16 cases, 7.69%). The breakdown of the patients with prosthesis dislocation as an endpoint event was the nondislocation group (166 cases, 79.81%), the anterior dislocation group (20 cases, 9.62%), and the posterior dislocation group (22 cases, 10.58%). The mean follow‐up was 2.5 years (SD 1.43; 1–5.2). Significantly, there were no significant differences in age, gender, primary diseases, or BMI in the two dislocation groups compared with that in the nondislocation group. However, in terms of radiological parameters, the parameters including CA (p < 0.05), ΔSS (p < 0.05), |PI‐LL| (p < 0.05), standing CSI (p < 0.05), and sitting CSI (p < 0.05) exhibited statistically significant differences between the anterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group. Furthermore, several parameters exhibited statistically significant differences between the posterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group, such as CA (p < 0.05), ΔSS (p < 0.05), |PI‐LL| (p < 0.05)|, standing CSI (p < 0.05), and sitting CSI (p < 0.05). The details were presented in Table 1.

caption.p: Differential analysis of different outcomes in patients with spinopelvic pathology.

fn.p: Note: All results except primary disease, gender, and side were presented as the mean ± standard deviation.

Abbreviations: ΔFO = disparity in bilateral femoral offset; ΔSS = changes of sacral slope; AS = ankylosing spondylitis; AVN = avascular necrosis; BMI = body mass index; CA = cup anteversion; CI = cup inclination; Cobb = cob angle; DDH = developmental dysplasia of the hip; LL = lumbar lordosis angle; OA = osteoarthritis; |PI‐LL| = absolute value of PI minus LL; PI = pelvic incidence; PT = pelvic tilt; RA = rheumatoid arthritis; sitting CSI = sitting combined sagittal index; SS = sacral slope; standing CSI = standing combined sagittal index; SVA = sagittal vertical axis; TK = thoracic kyphosis angle.
The results of T test or Chi‐square analysis for comparison between the posterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group.
The results of T test or Chi‐square analysis for comparison between the anterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group.

sec.title: Cut‐Off Value of Prediction Parameters for Prosthesis Dislocation After THA in Patients With Spinopelvic Pathology
sec.p: Compared with the nondislocation group, the cut‐off values for the prediction index were determined by the aforementioned T test analysis, indicating that the best cut‐off values for CA, |PI‐LL|, ΔSS, standing CSI, and sitting CSI were 23° (area under the curve, 0.918, p < 0.01), 10° (area under the curve, 0.784, p < 0.01), 13° (area under the curve, 0.806, p < 0.01), 227° (area under the curve, 0.781, p < 0.01), and 172° (area under the curve, 0.753, p < 0.01) in the anterior dislocation group, respectively. Moreover, the best cut‐off values for CA, |PI‐LL|, ΔSS, standing CSI, and sitting CSI were 11° (area under the curve, 0.934, p < 0.01), 13° (area under the curve, 0.715, p < 0.01), 13° (area under the curve, 0.749, p < 0.01), 218° (area under the curve, 0.668, p = 0.01), and 169° (area under the curve, 0.757, p < 0.01) in the posterior dislocation group, respectively (Figure 2).

caption.p: ROC curve of CA, ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, standing CSI, and sitting CSI. (A) ROC of anterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group; (B) ROC of posterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group. ΔSS = Changes of sacral slope; CA = cup anteversion; standing CSI = standing combined sagittal index; sitting CSI = sitting combined sagittal index; |PI‐LL| = absolute value of PI minus LL.

sec.title: Univariate and Multivariate Analysis
sec.p: The univariate and multivariate regression analyses were conducted to further investigate the effect of the above predictors on prosthesis dislocation, showing that these parameters, including ΔSS < 13° (OR = 4.015, p = 0.012), |PI‐LL| > 10° (OR = 4.163, p = 0.012), CA > 23° (OR = 4.276, p = 0.008), standing CSI > 227° (OR = 4.103, p = 0.011) were independently associated with anterior prosthesis dislocation. Meanwhile, these parameters, including ΔSS < 13° (OR = 6.046, p = 0.003), |PI‐LL| > 10° (OR = 3.717, p = 0.012), CA < 11° (OR = 8.738, p < 0.001), sitting CSI < 169° (OR = 4.468, p = 0.009) were independently associated with posterior prosthesis dislocation (Table 2, 3, 4).

caption.p: Univariate analysis of nondislocation and posterior dislocation.

fn.p: Abbreviations: ΔSS = changes of sacral slope; CA = cup anteversion; |PI‐LL| = absolute value of PI minus LL; standing CSI = standing combined sagittal index; sitting CSI = sitting combined sagittal index.

caption.p: Univariate analysis of nondislocation and anterior dislocation.

fn.p: Abbreviations: ΔSS = changes of sacral slope; CA = cup anteversion; |PI‐LL| = absolute value of PI minus LL; standing CSI = standing combined sagittal index; sitting CSI = sitting combined sagittal index.

Abbreviations: ΔSS = changes of sacral slope; CA = cup anteversion; |PI‐LL| = absolute value of PI minus LL; standing CSI = standing combined sagittal index; sitting CSI = sitting combined sagittal index.

sec.title: Nomogram for Predicting the Prosthesis Dislocation After THA in Patients With Spinopelvic Pathology
sec.p: According to the results of multivariate logistic regression analysis, two nomograms were drawn to predict the occurrence of prosthesis dislocation after THA in patients with spinopelvic pathology (Figure 3). The risk of anterior dislocation in patients with spinopelvic pathology was estimated by calculating the scores corresponding to each risk factor (ΔSS < 13°, |PI‐LL| > 10°, CA > 23°, standing CSI > 227°). In addition, the risk of posterior dislocation in patients with spinopelvic pathology was estimated by calculating the scores corresponding to each risk factor (ΔSS < 13°, |PI‐LL| > 13°, CA < 11°, sitting CSI < 169°). The AUROC curve of the models was 0.847 (95% CI: 0.757–0.936) and 0.824 (95% CI: 0.729–0.918). Then, the Hosmer‐Lemeshow test revealed that the χ 2 was 7.484 (p = 0.278) and 6.13 (p = 0.525), and the calibration plots for bootstrap resampling validation demonstrated satisfactory consistency (Figure 4).

caption.p: Nomogram for predicting prosthesis dislocation after THA. (A) Nomogram used for predicting anterior dislocation in patients with spinal pathology. (B) Nomogram used for predicting posterior dislocation in patients with spinal pathology. ΔSS = changes in sacral slope; CA = cup anteversion; |PI‐LL| = absolute value of PI minus LL; standing CSI = standing combined sagittal index; sitting CSI = sitting combined sagittal index.

ROC and calibration curve for prediction models. ROC curves of clinical prediction models based on the data of anterior dislocation (A) and posterior dislocation (B). Calibration curve of the nomogram based on the data of anterior dislocation (C) and posterior dislocation (D).

sec.title: Construction of “Personalized Safe Zone”
sec.p: The four distinct subgroups were classified by the HSCS, [21] included group 1A (81 cases, 38.9%), group 1B (36 cases, 17.3%), group 2A (59 cases, 28.3%), and group 2B (32, 15.3%). The “Personalized Safe Zone” for the acetabular cup placement in each groups were 1A (CA = 14.11° ± 4.57°, CI = 38.65° ± 6.32°), 1B (CA = 17.23° ± 3.15°, CI = 38.19° ± 5.45°), 2A (CA = 15.76° ± 4.08°, CI = 38.95° ± 6.21°), 2B (CA = 19.50° ± 3.73°, CI = 39.50° ± 6.48°), respectively (Table 5). Among them, compared with the anterior dislocation group and the posterior dislocation group, the CA in the nondislocation group exhibited statistically significant differences (p < 0.05). Additionally, the CA in the nondislocation group showed statistically significant differences compared across all four subgroups (p = 0.001). Furthermore, the CA of posterior dislocation patients varied among subgroups, showing that a greater CA was observed in the 1B and 2B groups (p = 0.032). This may be attributed to the decrease in pelvic mobility in patients with spinal stiffness, leading to the potential prosthesis impingement. It was worth noting that the safe zone in the four subgroups was situated within the “Lewinnek safe zone” demonstrating that the ranges of “Personalized Safe Zone” were more accurate and reliable (Figure 5).

caption.p: The ranges of CA and CI in different subgroups based on the HSCS.

fn.p: Note: The gray shaded area are only for the purpose of distinguishing between the two sets of data (CA value and CI value).
Abbreviations: CA = cup anteversion; CI = cup inclination.
The results of the T test for comparison between the posterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group.
The results of the T test for comparison between the anterior dislocation group and the nondislocation group.
The results of the analysis of variance for three groups.

caption.p: Comparison of “Personalized Safe Zone” and “Lewinnek safe zone” in each group. The red and blue box indicated the “Personalized Safe Zone” and “Lewinnek safe zone” in each group, respectively. CA = cup anteversion; CI = cup inclination.

sec.title: Clinical Validation of “Personalized Safe Zone”
sec.p: A total of 79 patients were collected in this study, including 38 cases in the group 1A (48.1%), nine cases in the group 1B (11.3%), 20 cases in the group 2A (25.3%), and 12 cases in the group 2B (15.1%), and then were divided into P‐THA (40 cases) and T‐THA group (39 cases), with the postoperative radiographic follow‐up of 12 months. As illustrated in Table 6, the patients in the P‐THA group exhibited a lower dislocation rate compared to that in the T‐THA group (p = 0.038). Remarkably, no patients with dislocation were found in the P‐THA group, while four patients with dislocation were observed in the T‐THA group, including two patients with posterior dislocation (one case in 1B subgroup and one case in 2B subgroup) and two patients with anterior dislocation in the 2B subgroup. Moreover, the patients in the P‐THA group also demonstrated a lower incidence of prosthetic impingement (p = 0.023). There were no differences in other radiographic outcomes, complications, and functional recovery.

fn.p: Note: All results except primary disease, gender, and side were presented as the mean ± standard deviation. The gray shaded area are only for the purpose of distinguishing between the two sets of data (CA value and CI value).

Abbreviations: AS = ankylosing spondylitis; AVN = avascular necrosis; BMI = body mass index; CA = cup anteversion; CI = cup inclination; DDH = developmental dysplasia of the hip; FJS‐12 = Forgotten Joint Score‐12; HSCS = hip–spine classification system; HSS = Harris hip score; LLD = leg length discrepancy; OA = osteoarthritis; p value = results of T test for comparison between the P‐THA group and the T‐THA group; RA = rheumatoid arthritis, standing CSI = standing combined sagittal index; sitting CSI = sitting combined sagittal index, VAS = Visual Analogue Scale/Score.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: This study aimed to reveal the risk factors of prosthesis dislocation after THA in patients with spinopelvic pathology and construct the clinical prediction models. Our results showed that: (1) the radiological parameters such as ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, standing CSI were the risk factor of prosthesis anterior dislocation and ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, sitting CSI were the risk factor of prosthesis posterior dislocation; (2) the “Personalized Safe Zone” was constructed based on the HSCS, indicating that the ranges of it were 1A (CA = 14.11 ± 4.57, CI = 38.65 ± 6.32), 1B (CA = 17.23 ± 3.15, CI = 38.19 ± 5.45), 2A (CA = 15.76 ± 4.08, CI = 38.95 ± 6.21), 2B (CA = 19.50 ± 3.73, CI = 39.50 ± 6.48), respectively, and the differences in the range of CA in each groups were statistically significant: (3) the clinical effectiveness of “Personalized Safe Zone” was validated in the cohort study, suggesting that the acetabular cup placement in THA according to the “Personalized Safe Zone” could reduce the probability of dislocation and the incidence of prosthetic impingement significantly.

sec.title: Definition of Functional Safe Zone
sec.p: The previous reports demonstrated that ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, PT, SS, LL, and other factors affected the acetabular cup placement during THA in patients with spinopelvic pathology, such as degenerative changes, AS, spinal deformities, rheumatoid spondylitis, or those who underwent long‐segment spinal fusion (three levels or more) [12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18]. Thus, a systematic regression analysis was designed in our studies, including spinal parameters, pelvic parameters, and spinopelvic parameters, and then the results showed that prosthesis dislocation after THA was susceptible to the parameters such as ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, and CSI, which was consistent with previous reports [26]. Likewise, the importance of standing and sitting CSI should be emphasized. The previous studies indicated that standing CSI < 243° was considered the safe range, while the values exceeding this threshold could lead to anterior dislocation due to the posterior prosthetic impingement during standing. Similarly, sitting CSI > 151° was deemed safe, whereas the values below this limitation could result in posterior dislocation due to the anterior prosthetic impingement during sitting. Therefore, the range of standing CSI < 243° and sitting CSI > 151° was defined as the functional safe zone [19, 20].

sec.title: Advantage of “Personalized Safety Zone”
sec.p: Although functional safe zone had been utilized for evaluating sagittal prosthesis impingement, its limitation of clinical significance was attributed to the absence of a precise safety range for the acetabular cup placement. According to the previous report [1], HSCS was used as the guidance for acetabular cup placement in THA, and this system fully considered the impact of ΔSS, |PI‐LL| on prosthesis positioning. Therefore, a “personalized safety zone” was established based on the “Lewinnek safe zone” design method [5] using HSCS in this study, demonstrating that the patients with spinopelvic pathology required an personalized acetabular cup placement to compensate the deficiency of spine and hip movement in different HSCS groups. Remarkablely, the range of “personalized safety zone” was more smaller than the “Lewinnek safe zone,” showing the better accuracy and reliability for the acetabular cup placement.

sec.title: Verification of “Personalized Safety Zone”
sec.p: Moreover, the clinical effectiveness of the “Personalized Safe Zone” was verified by a Cohort study. Our study demonstrated that the patients in P‐THA group had a lower dislocation and prosthesis impingement rate compared with that in T‐THA group. In details, four patients experienced dislocation in T‐THA group. Among of them, two patients had the CSI values outside the range of functional safe zone, two patients had the CSI values close to the threshold. Additionally, seven patients showed the prosthesis impingement in postoperative radiology in T‐THA group, indicating the potential risk for dislocation. It was worth noting that one patient with prosthetic impingement was identified in P‐THA group, which may be resulted from the excessive femoral anteversion angle due to the dysplasia. Thus, it was clear that the special prostheses with adjustable anteversion angle should be used in the patients with proximal femur dysplasia, such as Wagner cone and S‐ROM [27, 28, 29]. Furthermore, the CSI values in T‐THA group were closer to the threshold for functional safe zone than that in P‐THA group, although there was no statistically significant difference between the two groups, suggesting the potential risks for anterior or posterior prosthesis impingement during daily activities from standing to sitting.

sec.title: Strengths and Limitations
sec.p: In addition, our study with some limitations should be considered. First, the potential for selection bias arises from the retrospective design of the study. Second, the sample size and follow‐up time was insufficient. These reasons led to our inability to complete the external verification and the situation where there was no statistically significant difference in the functional score in the validation of “Personalized Safe Zone.” In future studies, a multicenter, large‐scale and long‐term follow‐up RCTS will be designed and conducted. It is worth noting that the transverse acetabular ligament and X‐rod were utilized for intraoperative positioning in this study, facilitating proper prosthesis placement within the “Personalized Safe Zone.” However, this freehand placement technique has demonstrated limited precision. To overcome this limitation, robotic‐assisted systems and advanced navigation technologies enable accurate positioning of the acetabular component within the “Personalized Safe Zone” through comprehensive preoperative planning and precise intraoperative execution.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: To summarize, the acetabular cup placement during THA in patients with spinopelvic pathology was influenced by various factors, including ΔSS, |PI‐LL|, CA, CSI. The novel “Personalized Safe Zone” based on HSCS reduced the occurrence of prosthesis dislocation and impingement, due to the emphasis on importance that the spine and pelvis should be considered as a whole.

Wenqian Xu: investigation, visualization. Zhiguang Chen: investigation, data curation. Jiawen Xia: funding acquisition. Yingxing Xu: conceptualization, methodology, investigation, data curation, validation, formal analysis, supervision, funding acquisition, project administration, resources, writing – original draft, writing – review and editing.

sec.title: Disclosure
sec.p: All authors are in agreement with the manuscript.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: This study was supported by grants from the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant number: 82260427); the Science and Technology Plan Project of Yunnan Province Technology Hall (Grant number: 202301AT070134); the Yunnan Revitalization Talent Support Program (Grant number: XDYC‐QNRC‐2023‐0198); the Yunnan Province medical discipline reserve talent project (Grant number: H‐2024030); and the PhD Research Fund Project of the First Affiliated Hospital of Kunming Medical University (Grant number: 2021BS016).

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The datasets generated and analyzed during the current study are not publicly available due to patient privacy protection but are available from the corresponding author on reasonable request.
